0.passage:
In pompous language, however, which jumbled one sentence into another, and at length grew disconnected, he gave me to understand that I was to lead the children altogether away from the Casino, and out into the park. Finally his anger exploded, and [MASK] added sharply:

"I suppose you would like to take them to the Casino to play roulette? Well, excuse my speaking so plainly, but I know how addicted you are to gambling. Though I am not your mentor, nor wish to be, at least I have a right to require that you shall not actually _compromise_ me."

"I have no money for gambling," I quietly replied.

1.passage:
Though I am not your mentor, nor wish to be, at least I have a right to require that you shall not actually _compromise_ me."

"I have no money for gambling," [MASK] quietly replied.

"But you will soon be in receipt of some," retorted the General, reddening a little as he dived into his writing desk and applied himself to a memorandum book.

3.passage:
From it he saw that he had 120 roubles of mine in his keeping.

"Let us calculate," [MASK] went on. "We must translate these roubles into thalers.

5.passage:
In silence I took the money.

"You must not be offended at what I say," [MASK] continued. "You are too touchy about these things.

10.passage:
The General eyed me doubtfully, for he did not know whether to be angry or merely to feel surprised that I should so far forget myself.

"Of course, one always learns _something everywhere_," said [MASK] in a careless, contemptuous sort of tone.

"In Paris, too, I had a dispute with a Pole," I continued, "and then with a French officer who supported him.

11.passage:
Of course, one always learns _something everywhere_," said the Frenchman in a careless, contemptuous sort of tone.

"In Paris, too, I had a dispute with a Pole," [MASK] continued, "and then with a French officer who supported him. After that a section of the Frenchmen present took my part.

13.passage:
They did so as soon as I told them the story of how once I threatened to spit into [MASK] s coffee."

"To spit into it?" the General inquired with grave disapproval in his tone, and a stare, of astonishment, while the Frenchman looked at me unbelievingly.

14.passage:
the General inquired with grave disapproval in his tone, and a stare, of astonishment, while the Frenchman looked at me unbelievingly.

"Just so," [MASK] replied. "You must know that, on one occasion, when, for two days, I had felt certain that at any moment I might have to depart for Rome on business, I repaired to the Embassy of the Holy See in Paris, to have my passport visaed.

19.passage:
But " the General began.

"What really saved you was the fact that you proclaimed yourself a heretic and a barbarian," remarked [MASK] with a smile. "Cela n  tait pas si b te."

"But is _that_ how Russian subjects ought to be treated?

That man was then a boy of ten and his family are still residing in Moscow."

"Impossible!" [MASK] spluttered.

Come what may, I _must_ have money," [MASK] said. "And get it somehow I will otherwise I shall be ruined."

I asked her what had happened during my absence.

Every moment we are expecting to receive news of the end."

Yet I am certain that the old lady has remembered me in her will."

"Yes, I believe that you _will_ come in for a good deal," [MASK] said with some assurance.

"Yes, for she is fond of me.

But how come you to think so?"

I answered this question with another one. "That Marquis of yours," [MASK] said, " is _he_ also familiar with your family secrets?"

"And why are you yourself so interested in them?" was her retort as she eyed me with dry grimness.

Because, though the Frenchman is the handsomer of the two, he is also the baser; whereas the Englishman is not only a man of honour, but ten times the wealthier of the pair."

"Yes? But then the Frenchman is a marquis, and the cleverer of the two," remarked [MASK] imperturbably.

"Is that so?

As usual, he did not finish his sentence.

73.passage:
That is my sole reason."

"Then are you so certain that your roulette-playing will get us out of our difficulties?" [MASK] inquired with a quizzical smile.

78.passage:
Nonetheless she insisted that I ought to go halves with her in the day s winnings, and offered me 800 g lden on condition that henceforth, I gambled only on those terms; but I refused to do so, once and for all stating, as my reason, that I found myself unable to play on behalf of any one else, "I am not unwilling so to do," I added, "but in all probability I should lose."

"Well, absurd though it be, I place great hopes on your playing of roulette," [MASK] remarked musingly; "wherefore, you ought to play as my partner and on equal shares; wherefore, of course, you will do as I wish."

Then she left me without listening to any further protests on my part.

No; I have never noticed whether she does so or not," I repeated with a smile.

To a certain extent that is true," assented the Frenchman with a self-satisfied air.

I beg pardon," [MASK] said. "Yet it would be difficult to say which is the worst of the two Russian ineptitude or the German method of growing rich through honest toil."

"What an extraordinary idea," cried the General.

What an extraordinary idea," cried the General.

I smiled, for I was rather glad to have a quarrel with them.

I smiled, for I was rather glad to have a quarrel with them.

I went on.

She made a contemptuous grimace.

"You must not be angry with me," [MASK] continued, "for making such a proposal. I am so conscious of being only a nonentity in your eyes that you need not mind accepting money from me.

[MASK] said. "Do not you also hope something from it? Did you not tell me again and again, two weeks ago, that you were certain of winning at roulette if you played here? And did you not ask me not to consider you a fool for doing so? Were you joking? You cannot have been, for I remember that you spoke with a gravity which forbade the idea of your jesting."

"True," I replied gloomily.

132.passage:
You cannot have been, for I remember that you spoke with a gravity which forbade the idea of your jesting."

"True," [MASK] replied gloomily. "I always felt certain that I should win.

138.passage:
Yet I dare wager that you do not think me capable of serious feeling in the matter?"

"I do not care whether you are so or not," answered [MASK] with calm indifference. "Well, since you ask me, I _do_ doubt your ability to take anything seriously.

Not a single one of the reasons which you have given can be looked upon as serious."

"By the way," [MASK] interrupted, "you say you want to pay off a debt. It must be a large one.

In all probability, too, your heart is not comely, and it is possible that your mind is wholly ignoble."

Why, for a mere fancy, should I go and insult a woman?"

195.passage:
Perhaps it was my costume which intimidated him, for I was well and fashionably dressed, after the manner of a man who belongs to indisputably good society.

"Ja wo-o-ohl!" cried [MASK] again with all my might with a longdrawn rolling of the "ohl" sound after the fashion of the Berliners (who constantly use the phrase "Ja wohl!" in conversation, and more or less prolong the syllable "ohl" according as they desire to express different shades of meaning or of mood).

At this the Baron and the Baroness faced sharply about, and almost fled in their alarm.

At the portico I caught up to her.

197.passage:
I have perpetrated the the piece of idiocy," I said as I came level with her.

Lolling on a divan close by was [MASK].

"With a German?

I felt a strong desire to overlay the incident with an even added measure of grossness; so, the further I proceeded, the more did the gusto of my proceeding increase.

"You are only making fun of me!" vociferated the General as, turning to the Frenchman, he declared that my bringing about of the incident had been gratuitous. [MASK] smiled contemptuously, and shrugged his shoulders.

216.passage:
You have entailed upon me the fact of my being forced to sue humbly to the Baron, and to give him my word of honour that this very day you shall cease to belong to my establishment!"

"Excuse me, General," [MASK] interrupted, "but did he make an express point of it that I should  cease to belong to your establishment,  as you call it?"

"No; I, of my own initiative, thought that I ought to afford him that satisfaction; and, with it he was satisfied.

The General on hearing of this further intended outrage, showed the white feather.

He was almost breathless with anger, as well as in a terrible fright.

"General," [MASK] replied with that calmness which he never could abide, "one cannot arrest a man for brawling until he has brawled. I have not so much as begun my explanations to the Baron, and you are altogether ignorant as to the form and time which my intended procedure is likely to assume.

234.passage:
It was one which was too outspoken for his taste and he had no mind to be frank with me.

"I am connected with the General," [MASK] said drily, "partly through business affairs, and partly through special circumstances. My principal has sent me merely to ask you to forego your intentions of last evening.

237.passage:
Good heavens!" cried [MASK]. "Seeing that the General takes such an interest in the matter, is there anything very unnatural in his desiring also to know your plans?"

We had lost!

The wheel whirled around and around, with the Grandmother simply quaking as she watched its revolutions.

The chair, with the old lady beaming in it, was wheeled away towards the doors at the further end of the salon, while our party hastened to crowd around her, and to offer her their congratulations.

The red turned up, but zero missed again, and we only got our thousand g lden back.

Begone with you and your views!" said the Grandmother angrily as she waved him away.

Here we are, Madame," [MASK] announced. "Here is the moneychanger s office."

At length, too, he smiled.

"Pray recollect yourself!" cried [MASK]. "And may my money choke you!

713.passage:
There you are!" [MASK] said as she nudged me. "See what we have won! Surely it would be worth our while to stake four thousand instead of a hundred, for we might win another four thousand, and then ! Oh, it was YOUR fault before all your fault!"

I felt greatly put out as I watched her play, but I decided to hold my tongue, and to give her no more advice.

714.passage:
and the Prince took their departure, and the General followed them.

"Madame, Madame," sounded the honeyed accents of [MASK] as he leant over to whisper in the Grandmother s ear. "That stake will never win.

719.passage:
At length he seized a pencil, and began to reckon sums on paper until he had exhausted the Grandmother s patience.

"Away with you!" [MASK] interrupted.

728.passage:
An hour later we had lost everything in hand.

"Home!" cried [MASK].

Not until we had turned into the Avenue did she utter a word; but from that point onwards, until we arrived at the hotel, she kept venting exclamations of "What a fool I am!

729.passage:
Home!" cried the Grandmother.

Not until we had turned into the Avenue did she utter a word; but from that point onwards, until we arrived at the hotel, [MASK] kept venting exclamations of "What a fool I am! What a silly old fool I am, to be sure!"

Arrived at the hotel, she called for tea, and then gave orders for her luggage to be packed.

731.passage:
We are off again," she announced.

"But whither, Madame?" inquired [MASK].

"What business is that of _yours?

740.passage:
For her part the Grandmother had nothing for the party but abuse.

"Away with you, you rascals!" [MASK] was shouting.

746.passage:
Then all at once she burst into a laugh and left the room crying to the General as she did so: "Elle vivra cent ans!"

"So you have been counting upon my death, have you?" fumed [MASK]. "Away with you!

"You need not say any more," interrupted [MASK] energetically. "I understand the situation.

756.passage:
Will you come with me or will you not?"

"First of all, let me ask of _you_," replied [MASK], "whether you are intending to depart at once?"

"What?

771.passage:
Or perhaps I am the only one who does not know about it?"

"Now, now! Do not frown," continued [MASK]. "But I do not intend to slur things over.

773.passage:
Good-bye."

"But let me stay with you a little longer," said [MASK].

"No," replied the other; "you need not.

797.passage: He seemed to be in a great hurry and much preoccupied, though in his face I could discern no actual traces of worry or perturbation. He held out to me a friendly hand, with [MASK] usual ejaculation of "Ah!" but did not check his stride. I turned and walked beside him, but found, somehow, that his answers forbade any putting of definite questions.

800.passage:
The thing interests me."

"Where have you been today?" [MASK] asked surprised at myself for having, as yet, omitted to put to him that question.

810.passage:
It was in vain that I protested, for he could understand nothing that was said to him, Next he started talking about the Grandmother, but always in a disconnected sort of fashion his one thought being to send for the police.

"In Russia," said [MASK], suddenly boiling over with indignation, "or in any well-ordered State where there exists a government, old women like my mother are placed under proper guardianship. Yes, my good sir," he went on, relapsing into a scolding tone as he leapt to his feet and started to pace the room, "do you not know this" (he seemed to be addressing some imaginary auditor in the corner) " do you not know this, that in Russia old women like her are subjected to restraint, the devil take them?" Again he threw himself down upon the sofa.

816.passage:
Then how will you pay your hotel bill?" [MASK] cried in consternation. "And what shall you do afterwards?"

He looked at me vaguely, but it was clear that he had not understood perhaps had not even heard my questions.

818.passage: Blanche. "What on earth am I to do?" [MASK] concluded.

826.passage: As I was passing the door of the General s suite, I met the nursemaid, and inquired after her master. "There is nothing new to report, sir," [MASK] replied quietly. Nevertheless I decided to enter, and was just doing so when I halted thunderstruck on the threshold.

827.passage:
The shock made me utter an exclamation.

"What is the matter? What is the matter?" [MASK] asked in a strange voice.

829.passage:
I re-echoed. "Why, the fact that you are _here!_"

"If I am here, I have come with all that I have to bring," [MASK] said. "Such has always been my way, as you shall presently see.

834.passage: All this is clear enough," [MASK] commented. "Surely you did not expect aught else from him?" Somehow I was feeling annoyed.

841.passage: Then an idea suddenly occurred to me. "What about the Grandmother?" [MASK] asked.

843.passage:
What makes you speak of _her?_" was her irritable inquiry. "I cannot go and live with her. Nor," [MASK] added hotly, "will I go down upon my knees to _any one_."

"Why should you?

845.passage:
Nor," she added hotly, "will I go down upon my knees to _any one_."

"Why should you?" [MASK] cried.

849.passage:
She smiled.

"If you were to do that," [MASK] said, "he would merely tell you to be so good as first to return him the fifty thousand francs. What, then, would be the use of having a quarrel with him?

851.passage:
I ground my teeth.

"The question," [MASK] went on, "is how to raise the fifty thousand francs. We cannot expect to find them lying about on the floor.

853.passage:
Her eyes flashed fire.

"What? _you yourself_ wish me to leave you for him?" [MASK] cried with a scornful look and a proud smile.

858.passage:
For with horror I had realised that I _must_ win, and that upon that stake there depended all my life.

"[MASK]!" called the croupier. I drew a long breath, and hot shivers went coursing over my body.

859.passage:
Upon my doing so there followed a moment of suspense only comparable to that which [MASK] must have experienced when, in Paris, she was descending earthwards from a balloon.

"Quatre!" called the croupier.

Once more, with the addition of my original stake, I was in possession of six thousand florins!

860.passage:
I had raked in thirty thousand florins, and again the bank had had to close for the night!

"Go away now, go away now," a voice whispered to [MASK] on my right. The person who had spoken to me was a certain Jew of Frankfurt a man who had been standing beside me the whole while, and occasionally helping me in my play.

862.passage:
At length two Jews stopped me near the exit.

"You are a bold young fellow," [MASK] said, "but mind you depart early tomorrow as early as you can for if you do not you will lose everything that you have won."

But I did not heed them.

864.passage:
I remember, too, how, without moving from her place, or changing her attitude, she gazed into my face.

"I have won two hundred thousand francs!" cried [MASK] as I pulled out my last sheaf of bank-notes. The pile of paper currency occupied the whole table.

869.passage:
Or, if you should prefer," [MASK] continued, "let me take them to him myself tomorrow yes, early tomorrow morning. Shall I?"

Then all at once she burst out laughing, and laughed for a long while.

871.passage:
I am _not_ going to take your money," she said contemptuously.

"Why not?" [MASK] cried.

879.passage:
Am _I_ De Griers?"

"You?" [MASK] cried with her eyes suddenly flashing.

882.passage:
Finally she threw herself upon me in an embrace.

"You love me?" [MASK] said.

885.passage: No, no!" [MASK] kept repeating. "_You_ are my dear one; _you_ are the man I trust." Again she laid her hands upon my shoulders, and again she gazed at me as she reiterated: "You love me, you love me?

886.passage: _You_ are my dear one; _you_ are the man I trust." Again she laid her hands upon my shoulders, and again she gazed at me as [MASK] reiterated: "You love me, you love me? Will you _always_ love me?" I could not take my eyes off her.

888.passage: Yes, yes, he is there," [MASK] said. "Open the window, and see if he is not." She pushed me in that direction; yet, no sooner did I make a movement to obey her behest than she burst into laughter, and I remained beside her, and she embraced me.

889.passage:
She pushed me in that direction; yet, no sooner did I make a movement to obey her behest than she burst into laughter, and I remained beside her, and she embraced me.

"Shall we go away tomorrow?" presently [MASK] asked, as though some disturbing thought had recurred to her recollection.

I handed it to her.

For a moment I reflected.

"No!" [MASK] shouted.

961.passage: she would say to me with air of absolute simplicity; and I never disputed the point. Nevertheless, though she fitted out her flat very badly with the money, the fact did not prevent [MASK] from saying when, later, she was showing me over the rooms of her new abode: "See what care and taste can do with the most wretched of means!" However, her "wretchedness" had cost fifty thousand francs, while with the remaining fifty thousand she purchased a carriage and horses.

This seemed to her so curious that straightway she seated herself by my side.

"You see," [MASK] went on, "I decided to spend so much upon these horses only because I can easily sell them again. They would go at any time for _twenty_ thousand francs."

"Yes, yes.

973.passage:
[MASK] exclaimed. "Mais tu as l esprit pour comprendre. Sais-tu, mon gar on, although you are a tutor, you ought to have been born a prince. Are you not sorry that your money should be going so quickly?"

"No.

1008.passage: I could scarcely believe my eyes! "They may come in handy for you," [MASK] explained, "for, though you are a very learned tutor, you are a very stupid man. More than two thousand francs, however, I am not going to give you, for the reason that, if I did so, you would gamble them all away.

1010.passage:
As soon as he perceived me, he called me by name, and I went and sat down beside him; but, on noticing that he seemed a little stiff in his manner, I hastened to moderate the expression of joy which the sight of him had called forth.

"_You_ here?" [MASK] said.

1012.passage:
In fact, your whole life during the past twenty months lies within my knowledge."

"How closely you watch the doings of your old friends!" [MASK] replied.

1018.passage:
Evidently he had expected to see me looking more crushed and broken than I was.

"Well," [MASK] said not very pleasantly, "I am none the less glad to find that you retain your old independence of spirit, as well as your buoyancy."

"Which means that you are vexed at not having found me more abased and humiliated than I am?

1020.passage:
Well," he said not very pleasantly, "I am none the less glad to find that you retain your old independence of spirit, as well as your buoyancy."

"Which means that you are vexed at not having found me more abased and humiliated than I am?" [MASK] retorted with a smile.

1026.passage:
At that time it was ages since I had last looked at a paper or turned the pages of a book.

"You are growing blas ," [MASK] said. "You have not only renounced life, with its interests and social ties, but the duties of a citizen and a man; you have not only renounced the friends whom I know you to have had, and every aim in life but that of winning money; but you have also renounced your memory.

1032.passage:
In fact, I will bet you a wager that I shall do so."

1052.passage:
You are saying this because you are feeling bitter," said [MASK] with cold indifference. "Yet there is not the least originality in your words."

"I agree.

1056.passage:
Yes, you are, for you are only talking nonsense!" exclaimed my companion his voice now trembling and his eyes flashing fire. "Are you aware," [MASK] continued, "that wretched, ignoble, petty, unfortunate man though you are, it was at _her_ request I came to Homburg, in order to see you, and to have a long, serious talk with you, and to report to her your feelings and thoughts and hopes yes, and your recollections of her, too?"

"Indeed?

1058.passage:
Never before had this happened.

"Yes, poor unfortunate," continued [MASK]. "She _did_ love you; and I may tell you this now for the reason that now you are utterly lost.
